question: How to Draw Boxing Gloves? Provide steps visually and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. 1. Begin by drawing an oval. This will help you to sketch the first glove. 2. 2. Use a curved line to enclose a rounded rectangular shape on top of the oval. This forms the wrist of the glove. 3. 3. Erase the oval from the wrist. Then, enclose a rectangle across the wrist. 4. 4. Erase one side of the oval. Use overlapping curved lines to form the glove's thumb and mitten. Use short curved lines to draw a starburst pattern at the point where the two lines meet. 5. 5. Draw a second oval overlapping the first glove. Erase as necessary. 6. 6. Erase the top of the oval and sketch in a rectangular shape with rounded corners. It should overlap the first glove, so erase as necessary. This forms the wrist of the glove. Then, enclose another rectangular shape within the first. Draw curved lines across the base of the glove to indicate the curvature of the material. 7. 7. Erase the side of the oval. Outline the thumb and mitten of the glove using two overlapping curved lines. Use shorter curved lines to draw a starburst pattern at the point where the two lines meet. Then, draw a curved line from the wrist to this junction, indicating a seam. 8. 8. Draw a circle above the gloves. This will form the hook from which the gloves hang. Draw a "U" shaped line above it. Below it, extend two curved lines and double them back upon themselves. Then, draw pairs of lines from the hook to each glove. This represents the string used to hang the gloves. 9. 9. Detail the glove. Draw curved lines across the wrist and side of the glove to indicate wrinkles and seams. 10. Color your boxing gloves. They are typically red.
generated_text:
Here are the **text steps** (separate from the visual):

1. Shapes & pose
   Lightly sketch two tall ovals for the glove bodies, tilted slightly toward each other. Add a short horizontal line beneath each for the wrist opening.

2. Cuffs
   Turn each wrist line into a short “cuff cylinder”: draw a thin rectangle wrapping the base of each oval.

3. Knuckle dome
   Round the top of each oval into a smooth dome. Add a soft, shallow curve near the top front to suggest the knuckle ridge.

4. Thumbs
   On the inner side of each glove, attach a teardrop/bean shape for the thumb pad. Its tip points toward the knuckle ridge; its base connects near the cuff.

5. Palm panel
   Inside each glove, sketch a curved panel that starts under the thumb, swoops across the palm, and meets the cuff—this is the padded palm section.

6. Clean silhouette
   Trace a single confident outline around each glove (dome → front knuckle → thumb → palm → cuff). Erase construction lines.

7. Details & seams
   Add short dashed or stitched lines along the knuckle ridge, around the thumb base, and near the cuff edge. If you prefer laces, sketch a narrow opening on the front of one glove with an “X-X-X” lace pattern; otherwise add a simple strap rectangle.

8. Overlap & depth
   Decide which glove sits slightly forward. Thicken that glove’s outer contour a bit more and let it overlap the other to create depth.

9. Shading
   Pick a light source (e.g., top-left). Lightly shade the underside of the knuckle dome, the inner thumb curve, and the gap between gloves. Darken the cuff underside. Keep the top planes lighter.

10. Highlights
    Leave slim unshaded arcs along the upper knuckle and thumb to suggest glossy padding.

11. Final linework
    Go over the main contour with a steady, slightly thicker line; keep stitching and fold lines thinner so they read as surface detail.

12. Color (optional)
    Fill the gloves with a base color (classic red works well). Add a darker tone along the shaded edges and a lighter tint on top planes. Keep cuffs a touch darker than the glove body.

Want the steps as a printable handout or in a different style (cartoon, realistic, vintage)? I can format that too.

question: How to draw a pumpkin? Provide steps visually and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. 1. Draw an oval or egg shape to create the first rib of the pumpkin. Then, enclose another curved shape alongside it to create a second rib. 2. 2. Continue using long curved lines to enclose rounded ribs until the pumpkin has a round, full shape. 3. 3. Draw the pumpkin's thick stem. Extend two curved lines from the top of the pumpkin. From each of these, draw a long curved line. The lines should be roughly parallel and "S" shaped. 4. 4. Use a curved line to enclose the end of the stem. Draw another curved line across it to give the tip of the stem an oval shape. Then, texture the stem with curved lines. Use additional short lines to begin enclosing the ribs visible behind the stem. 5. 5. Complete the pumpkin's ribs. Then, draw tendrils of vine terminating from the stem. Use long, curving, "S" shaped lines. 6. 6. Draw a leaf along the pumpkin vine. First, extend a curved line from the vine. This forms the leaf's stem and vein. Then, use a series of connected, curved lines to outline the body of the leaf. 7. 7. Continue to draw the body of the leaf on the opposite side of the vein. Then, draw secondary veins extending from the primary vein or midrib. 8. 8. Draw the remaining veins, and begin a second leaf. Again, use a curved line for the stem and a series of curved lines to sketch the outline of the leaf. 9. 9. Complete the leaf, erasing as necessary. Finish outlining the leaf, and draw the secondary veins. 10. Color your pumpkin. Traditionally, pumpkins are orange in color. They can also be yellow, brown, green, or white!
generated_text:
Here are the **text steps** (the visual guide is attached above):

1. Sketch the body
   Draw a wide oval. Add a faint vertical guideline down the center.

2. Add the outer ribs
   On the left and right, draw two long C-shaped curves that hug the oval—these are the outer pumpkin lobes.

3. Fill in the middle ribs
   Add 2–3 more curved ribs between the outer ones, all meeting near the top and bottom to suggest depth.

4. Shape the top and bottom
   Flatten the bottom with a shallow curve so it can “sit.” At the top, tuck the ribs slightly inward to form a little dip.

5. Draw the stem
   From the top dip, sketch a short, slightly curved stem (think a bent cylinder). Add a notch or two where it meets the pumpkin.

6. Optional leaf & vine
   Add a simple leaf beside the stem and a loose curly vine for character.

7. Clean lines
   Erase the original oval and any overlaps you don’t need. Thicken the outer contour slightly to make the form pop.

8. Shade & color
   Color the pumpkin a warm orange. Deepen the creases between ribs with a darker orange/brown, keep the front planes lighter, color the stem green-brown, and add a soft shadow under the pumpkin.

Quick tips

* Keep rib curves widest at the middle and narrower near top/bottom.
* If it looks too round, widen the oval; if too flat, make it taller.
* Highlights along one side instantly make it look glossy.

question: How to draw a cartoon snail? Provide steps visually and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. 1. Begin the cartoon snail outline by drawing the snail's head. First, draw two circles. These will become the snail's eyes. Draw a curved line across each circle. In the lower half of the circle, draw a pie chart or Pacman shape - a circle with a missing triangular slice. What does a Pacman shape look like, exactly? Check out this Pacman pixel art . Below each eye, extend two curved lines. These are the snail's eyestalks. Then, connect the stalks with an overlapping curved line, contouring the snail's face. 2. 2. Continue the line of the face. This line should be long and wavy, outlining the bottom of the sticky, slimy foot. 3. 3. Draw another wavy line roughly parallel to the foot, allowing the lines to meet at a point. Draw two curved lines across the face, forming the smiling mouth and the chin. Place a short curved line at the corner of the mouth. 4. 4. Extend the remaining side of the head with a long curved line. Double the line back on itself at the end to begin constructing the base of the shell. Connect the tip of the foot to the shell with a curved line. 5. 5. Begin the spiral shape of the snail shell by drawing a large "C" shaped line. Connect it to the snail's head with a short line. 6. 6. Continue the line of the shell to enclose the circle. Continue the line past the point of completion to begin the spiral pattern. 7. 7. Continue the spiral-shaped line. 8. 8. Enclose partial circles all along the spiral line. Notice that the circles grow smaller near the inside of the spiral. 9. 9. Fill the snail shell with more circular spots. Color your cartoon snail. We've given ours a green and yellow body with a tan and brown spotted snail. 10. Throughout much of the world, garden snails are usually brown in color. But some snails - especially the ocean and marsh-dwelling snails - have vivid black-and-white patterns or unusually bright colors .

question: How to boil pasta perfectly? Provide a visual guide and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. Fill a large pot about 2/3 full of water. Since the pasta needs lots of room to move around as it cooks, use a big pot. For example, if you'll be cooking a 1 pound (450 g) box of pasta, get out a pot that's at least 4 US quarts (3.8 L) in size. Then, pour in enough water to come 2/3 up the side of the pot. If you use a pot that's too small, your pasta is more likely to clump together as it cooks. 2. Cover the pot and bring the water to a boil. Set the pot of water on the stove and put a lid on it. Turn the burner to high and let the water come to a boil. You'll know the water is boiling when you see steam escaping from under the lid. Covering the pot with a lid will make the water boil faster. 3. Add salt and 1 pound (450 g) of pasta to the boiling water. Once the water boils vigorously, remove the lid and add 1 tablespoon (17 g) of salt and 1 pound (450 g) of pasta. If you're cooking long noodles, such as spaghetti, that don't fit in the pot, wait about 30 seconds and then push them into the water using a spoon or pasta fork. The salt will season the noodles as they cook, which will give you flavorful pasta. If you're unsure how many servings of pasta to cook, check the side of the box for recommended serving sizes. 4. Set a timer for 3 to 8 minutes. Stir the noodles with a pasta fork to break the noodles up and leave the lid off the pot. Then, check the pasta package for a recommended cooking time and set a timer for the minimum time that's suggested. For example, if the box says to cook the noodles for 7 to 9 minutes, set a timer for 7 minutes. Thin pasta, such as angel hair, will cook faster than thick or long noodles, such as fettuccine or penne, which take closer to 8 or 9 minutes. 5. Stir the noodles occasionally as they boil. The water should continue to bubble as the pasta cooks. Stir it every few minutes to prevent the noodles from sticking together. If the water looks like it might boil over the sides of the pot, turn the burner down to medium-high. 6. Bite into a noodle to see if it's cooked enough for you. Carefully scoop a noodle out of the water when the timer beeps and set it aside to cool a little. Bite into the noodle to tell if it's still hard in the center or if it's as soft as you like. Most people prefer to cook pasta until it's al dente, which means it's still a little firm in the center. If the pasta is still too hard for your liking, boil it for another minute before checking it again.

Here’s your **text guide**. The **visual guide** is attached above as an infographic.

# Text Guide: How to Boil Pasta Perfectly

1. Pick the pot + water

* Use a big pot so pasta can move freely.
* Water: **4–6 quarts (4–5.5 L) per 1 lb / 450 g** pasta.

2. Salt like the sea

* Add salt once the water is hot but before the pasta goes in.
* Aim for **1–2% salinity** (about **1½–2 Tbsp kosher salt** or **1 Tbsp table salt** per 4–6 quarts). This seasons the pasta itself.

3. Rolling boil first

* Wait for a **vigorous, rolling boil (100°C / 212°F)** before adding pasta. Lids help you get there; remove the lid once boiling.

4. Add pasta & stir early

* Drop pasta in and **stir for the first 1–2 minutes** to prevent sticking, then stir occasionally.

5. Cook to al dente (taste, don’t guess)

* Start tasting **2 minutes before** the package’s low end.
* Al dente = cooked through with a pleasant bite and no chalky center.

6. Save some pasta water

* **Reserve ½–1 cup** starchy water before draining. It helps sauces cling and lets you adjust thickness.

7. Drain, don’t rinse

* **Do not rinse** (you’ll wash off starch). Only rinse if making a **cold pasta salad**.

8. Marry pasta with sauce

* Finish pasta **in a pan with the sauce** for 1–2 minutes, loosening with splashes of reserved water and finishing with a knob of butter or olive oil if desired. Season to taste.

9. Rest & serve hot

* Let it sit **30–60 seconds** off heat to settle the sauce; plate immediately.

---

## Quick Timing Reference (start tasting early!)

* **Fresh pasta (eggs)**: 2–4 min
* **Dry thin long (spaghetti, linguine)**: 8–10 min
* **Dry short (penne, rigatoni, fusilli)**: 9–12 min
* **Thick/shape with ridges or whole wheat**: 11–13+ min
* **Gluten-free**: often **less forgiving**—taste frequently in the last few minutes.

---

## Common Mistakes & Fixes

* **Pot too small** → water cools off and pasta sticks. Use a larger pot.
* **Under-salting** → flat flavor. Salt the water properly.
* **Adding pasta before a full boil** → gummy texture. Wait for the rolling boil.
* **Not stirring early** → clumps. Stir in the first 1–2 minutes.
* **Overcooking** → mush. Taste early and often.
* **Rinsing after draining** → sauce won’t cling. Don’t rinse unless for cold dishes.

---

## Pro Tips

* For silky sauces, emulsify: **toss pasta + sauce + reserved water** over medium heat until glossy.
* Cooking for later? **Undercook by ~1 minute**, then finish in sauce when reheating.
* High altitude: water boils at a lower temp—**add a minute or two** and rely on tasting.

question: How to organize your closet? Provide illustrated steps and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. Remove all of the clothes from your closet. Take all of your clothes off their hangers and out of any bins or drawers in your closet. Fold them in piles on the floor or on your bed. This includes your shoes as well. It may also include other accessories such as belts, scarves, purses, or ties. 2. Decide which clothes you will keep. You may have the urge to keep everything, or toss everything. But go through systematically and piece by piece to really scrutinize your clothing. What you want in your closet are clothes that you wear on a regular basis, that fit you and are functional, and fit in the space available. Does the item fit? Clothing in the closet should fit you properly, neither too loose nor too tight. It typically means it is comfortable, not pinching, clothing can button easily, and no red marks left on the skin. It may also mean letting go of items no longer in fashion, such as skin tight skirts you really should not wear to your professional job. It is usually best to let go of "inspirational items" such as the jeans you hope to someday fit back into; trends being what they are the item may well be out of fashion when you do lose the weight. One pair of "fat pants" may be OK to remind you of your weight loss accomplishment. If your weight is fluctuating up or down (such as in growing young adults, pregnant women, or dieters) this may be tricky. Still, get rid or store items that clearly do not fit you. Do I wear this? Have you worn the item in the last year? How often do you wear it: once a week or only once this year? If you have not worn the item in a long time, that may well indicate it is time to let go. Special use items may be OK to keep even if used only periodically. You might have a Christmas sweater, or interview outfit, or formal dress that isn't used often but still worth having available. Do I like this? If you really don't like an item, do not keep it. In general, do not hang onto items out of guilt--such as that shirt your father bought you but you just do not like. Do I have multiples of this? Work or school uniforms are one thing. But if you have seven black almost identical t-shirts, that might be a sign to let go of a few. Make a "Keep" pile for the clothes that you will keep and wear on a regular basis. 3. Decide which clothes you will store. You should store the clothes that you won't be wearing for a while because they aren't seasonally appropriate. If it's the middle of summer, you can store your winter sweaters and scarves, and if it's the dead of winter, you can store your tank tops and summer dresses. You can also store clothes that may have sentimental value for you, such as a shirt your grandmother knitted for you, or an old t-shirt from your high school tennis team that no longer fits. Try to keep the sentimental value clothes to a minimum, though. Clothes are meant to be worn, after all. Consider displaying beloved clothing instead of keeping them in your closet. Consider framing your prized concert T-shirt, or creating a shadow box of your Boy Scout uniform and awards, or make a T-shirt quilt of your old marathon shirts. When you're done sorting through the clothes you will store, put them in a plastic bin or a clear bag marked keep. You can either store them in the back of your closet, under your bed, or in a storage unit or a different part of your home if you have the room. 4. Decide which clothes you will donate or throw out. This is the hardest step, and the most important. If you want to have a truly organized closet, then your goal should be to get rid of as many items of clothing as possible. This doesn't mean you should throw out your favorite things - however, it does mean that you should take a long hard look to ask yourself which clothes you will actually ever wear again. If you haven't worn something in over a year and it has no sentimental value, it's time to donate it. If you have an item that is so worn, covered in moth holes, or faded that you and anyone else will never wear it again, then it's time to throw it out. If you have a few items of clothing that are just way too small, stop waiting for the day that they will fit and donate them. Donate all of the clothes you don't need that are in good condition, or give them to a sibling or friend. 5. Clean the inside of the closet. You should do this before you put back your clothes. Vacuum or sweep the floor, wipe the walls down with all-purpose cleaner, and sweep away any cobwebs that may have accumulated there. If you want to make any changes, such as painting the inside a different color or adding and removing some shelves, do it now. 6. Hang up your clothes and organize them. Try to hang up as many of your clothes as you can. This will make it easier for you to find your clothes and to conserve space. You should not only hang up your clothes, but you should also organize them in a particular way so you can easily find them whenever you need to. Here are some ways to organize the clothes you hang up: Organize your clothes by season. If you've stored away some of your seasonal clothes, organize your clothes by season just for half the year. If it's summer, hang up your summer clothes first, followed by your fall clothes. Organize your clothes by type. You can separate your tank tops, shirts, pants, skirts, and dresses. Organize your work and casual clothes. Separate your work clothes from your casual clothes so you can easily get dressed for work in the morning. Organize your clothes by how often you wear them. You can choose any method of organization, but hang up a few key items, like your favorite hoodie or the pair of jeans you wear all the time, in the most accessible place. If you really want to step it up a notch, you can use differently colored hangers to mark a different type of clothing. For example, you can hang your tops on pink hangers, or your work clothes on green hangers. Colour code your clothes. example in rainbow colours You can also think about installing another pole to hang up your additional clothes. 7. Put additional clothes in other parts of your closet. Once you've hung up all of the clothes fit on your pole, you should find other parts of the closet to store the rest of your clothes. The clothes that you put in the bins should be used less frequently than the clothes you hang up, or they should be clothes that don't need to be hung up, like your workout clothes. Here are a few ideas: Don't waste the space under your hanging clothes. Put a few plastic bins of clothes under the hanging clothing. If you have room for a dresser, consider putting one in your closet. It will save you time and space. Consider installing a closet organizer to find a more efficient way to store your remaining clothes . If you have overhead space, make the most of it. Use it to store bulky sweaters, sweats, and other items that are thick and easy to spot. 8. Organize your shoes. Your shoes may take up a lot of the space in your closet, so once you've chosen which shoes you will keep, it's important to make the most of your space by storing them in the most organized and efficient manner. Here are some ways to organize the shoes in your closet: Organize them by type. Separate your dress shoes, sandals, and boots. Organize them by how often you wear them. Keep your favorite pair of boots, flip-flops, or sneakers in the place with the easiest access. Invest in a shoe rack to place on the floor of your closet. This will make it much easier to find the pair of shoes you want. Try storing your shoes in your overhead space. This is another easy way to save space. If your closet has a door that opens instead of a sliding door, consider getting a hanging shoe rack. If you have a front hall closet, consider putting the shoes you wear the most often there instead to save space in your personal closet. 9. Organize any boxes in your closet. If your closet is big enough, then it's likely that you've stored things other than clothes in it, such as big boxes filled with mementos, old photo albums, and CDs you haven't seen for ten years. To finish organizing your closet, you should go through these old boxes to see what you should keep and what you should toss. Here's how to do it: Get rid of any papers or items you've kept for over a year that have no sentimental value. Consolidate the boxes to save closet space. If your closet is already cramped, consider putting some of the items in a different place, such as putting your old high school yearbooks on the bottom of your bookshelf. If you've been using cardboard boxes, trade them up for plastic bins. They will last longer and will be more visually appealing. Label the boxes or bins so you know what's in them next time you move or organize your things again. 10. Organize any additional items in your closet. Take the time to go through any additional items in your closet to make sure that you still need them and that the closet is really the best place for them. Here are some examples: If you find any towels, sheets, or blankets, put them in your linen closet. If you've had an old lawn chair or another piece of furniture you don't really need hanging out back there, it's time to throw it out. If you've had to pick up an item and spend at least fifteen seconds trying to figure out what the heck it is or why you would need it, it's time to throw it out. Make sure that all of the other items you find belong in the closet and not another part of your home. For example, if you find a box of light bulbs, a box of comic books, or a box of chocolate, ask yourself if those items wouldn't be more logically organized elsewhere. 11. Make your closet more visually appealing. Turn your creativity loose and think of ways to add pleasure to the routine of getting dressed and looking through your closet every day. If you spend more time making your closet look nice, then you will be less likely to let it get messy in the future. Paint your closet a soft pretty color. Add mirrors for sparkle. Hang jewelry and scarves where you can see them -- as long as they don't get in your way. Hang up a small poster or painting that makes you smile every time you open your closet. 12. Enjoy your newly organized closet. Take a step back and admire your hard work! Hopefully, your closet is organized now so that all of its contents are easy to find and its overall appearance is to your liking. If not, take a few more minutes to make any minor changes that still need to be made. From this point forward, try to keep your closet organized as you add to it, or remove and return its current contents. Doing so will prevent you from needing to do another large overhaul on your closet in the future.
generated_text:
# Closet Organization — Step-by-Step Guide (Text)

## Supplies

* Matching slim hangers (all the same style)
* 3–5 sorting bins/bags (Keep, Donate, Tailor/Fix, Trash, Seasonal)
* Clear bins with lids, shelf dividers, labels, shoe rack or boxes
* Tape measure, sticky notes, marker

## The 8 Steps

1. **Empty & Sort**
   Pull everything out. As you go, drop items into: Keep / Donate / Tailor-Fix / Trash / Seasonal. Keep sentimental items in a separate small box.

2. **Declutter Fast**
   For each item ask: *Do I wear it? Does it fit? Do I love it?* If it fails 2+ questions, let it go. Put donations straight into your car or schedule a pickup.

3. **Measure & Plan Zones**
   Measure width, height to shelf, and depth. Sketch zones: **Long hang**, **Short hang (double rod if possible)**, **Shelves/Drawers**, **Shoes**, **Accessories**.

4. **Choose the Right Tools**

   * Hangers: one style for tops/bottoms, sturdy for coats.
   * Shelves: add dividers for stacks.
   * Bins: clear or labeled for accessories and off-season.
   * Over-the-door/side-wall hooks for bags, hats, scarves.

5. **Group by Category**
   Tops → Bottoms → Dresses → Outerwear → Activewear → Accessories → Shoes. Keep sets (suit pieces) together.

6. **Arrange Smart**

   * **Frequency:** everyday items at eye/hand level; occasion or off-season up high.
   * **Color order (light → dark)** within each category.
   * Face items the same way; one item per hanger. File-fold tees in drawers.

7. **Use Vertical Space**
   Add a second rod for short items, under-shelf baskets, and stackable boxes on the top shelf. Use floor space for a shoe rack; store rarely used items highest.

8. **Label & Maintain**
   Label shelves and bins (e.g., “Sweaters,” “Gym,” “Bags”). Do a 5-minute tidy each week; do a seasonal swap twice a year.

## Quick Layout Tips

* **Tiny reach-in:** Double-rod 2/3 of the width; one narrow long-hang section; over-door hooks; under-bed box for off-season.
* **Standard reach-in:** One long-hang, one double-hang, one shelf stack with dividers; 2–3 clear bins up top.
* **Walk-in:** U-shape: long-hang on the shortest wall, double-hang on others; drawers/shelves in the center; island only if walk path remains ≥ 36".

## Maintenance Mini-Routine (10 minutes)

* Return strays, re-fold one stack, re-set hangers to face forward, toss one item you won’t wear, and empty donation bag when it fills.

question: Why are there different shades of stone on the Washington Monument? Provide a photo and explain.
reference_text: Construction stopped in 1854 due to lack of funds, then resumed decades later with marble from a different quarry. The mismatch created a permanent color line in the obelisk.
generated_text: Here's the explanation (text), separate from the generated photo above:The Washington Monument's color changes partway up because construction stopped for decades. Builders laid the first ~150 feet (1848–1854) using one set of marble. Funding troubles and then the Civil War halted work. When construction resumed in the late 1870s and finished in 1884, crews used marble from different quarry seams (and some from a different quarry entirely). Those stones didn't match perfectly—and over time they weathered differently—so you see a distinct horizontal "color line" and slight banding higher up.

question: How to do an overhead press with dumbbells? Provide visual steps and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. Exhale as you raise the weights above the head in a controlled motion. 2. Pause briefly at the top of the motion. 3. Inhale and return the dumbbells to the shoulders.

Here are the **text steps** to go with the visual:

# Dumbbell Overhead Press — Text Steps

1. **Setup**

* Stand with feet about shoulder-width, toes slightly out.
* Hold a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height, palms facing in or slightly forward.
* **Wrists neutral** (straight), forearms vertical, elbows a bit in front of the torso.
* Draw ribs down, squeeze glutes, and keep a light bend in the knees.

2. **Brace**

* Big inhale through the belly, tighten abs like you’re about to be poked.
* Pack the shoulders (down and slightly back). Keep gaze forward.

3. **Press Up**

* Drive the dumbbells **up and slightly back**, letting your head move a touch back so the bells travel close to your face.
* Keep ribs from flaring; maintain tight glutes and abs.
* Elbows stay under (or just in front of) the wrists—don’t let them flare wide.

4. **Lockout**

* Finish with arms straight, **biceps near ears**, shoulders down (no shrug).
* Exhale at the top or through the sticking point. Pause briefly under control.

5. **Lower**

* Pull the weights back to shoulders on a controlled 2–3-second descent.
* Keep torso tall; don’t lean back or arch.

6. **Breathe & Repeat**

* Reset your brace each rep. Perform 6–12 reps for hypertrophy or 3–6 for strength.
* Stop 1–2 reps shy of form breakdown.

---

### Quick Tips

* Start lighter than you think; build up in 2–5 lb jumps.
* If your low back arches, **tighten abs and glutes** or switch to a half-kneeling stance.

### Common Mistakes → Fixes

* **Flaring ribs / big back arch** → Squeeze glutes, exhale, knit ribs down.
* **Bent-back wrists** → Stack knuckles over forearms; grip the handles firmly.
* **Press path in front** → Aim slightly back at the top so bells finish over mid-foot.
* **Shrugging** → Keep shoulder blades set down; don’t chase height with traps.

### Variations

* **Seated press** for more stability.
* **Arnold press** for extra front-delt/rotation work.
* **Single-arm press** to train anti-lean core control.

Stay smooth and pain-free—if you feel shoulder pinching, reduce range, rotate palms in, or stop.

question: How to do a back extension on a bench? Show visual steps and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. Start in a squatting position. Bend your knees and come close to the floor, almost as though you are going to sit. Hover just above the ground, with your thighs hugging close to your calves. As you get more comfortable with this move, you can start from a standing squat. Eventually you will start from a completely standing position. 2. Round your back. Bend your elbows close to your body so that your hands are by your ears. Tuck your head between your arms and curl your back forwards. As you get more comfortable with the position, you can start with your hands extended out in front of you. 3. Roll backwards. When your head hits the mat, tuck your chin and push the ground with your hands. Think about pushing your body away from the mat with your hands. Be sure to keep your shoulders and arms strong and close to your head. They are your point of strength. 4. Swing your legs over your head. Using the momentum of your legs and the strength of your arms, bring your legs over your head and your feet to the mat. You may have to use your core strength as well. Kick your legs to gain momentum, but squeeze your abs to pull your feet to the mat. 5. Stand up. Once your feet hit the mat, press against the mat with your hands, pushing your upper body up to follow your feet. You will be in a squat with your hands on the mat. Stand up from there, with your arms up. In order to practice for your back extension, you can practice ending in a pushup position instead of a standing position. When your feet hit the mat, press against the mat with your hands and use your ab muscles to straighten out into a plank position. Hold that position to build strength.

question: How to perform a deadlift with proper form? Provide visual steps and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. Prepare the barbell. Place the barbell on the ground in front of you and add plates according to your strength and fitness level. If it is your first time performing the deadlift, start lighter. It is always easy to add weight later. You want to perfect your form before you test your physical limits. Secure the plates tightly onto the barbell with clips to keep them from slipping around. Beginners usually start lifting just the barbell, since a typical barbell weighs between 25 and 45 pounds on its own. In this case, you'll want to prop the bar up so it's as high on your shins as it would be if it had plates (approximately 6-8 inches). Otherwise, you'll be bending too far down to pull the barbell right off the floor and could injure yourself. When you prop the barbell, be carefully that it can't easily roll off. 2. Set your stance. Step up to the bar so that your feet are approximately shoulder width apart, your toes are pointing forward or slightly outward, and the barbell is at the midpoint of your foot (as if it's dividing the front and the back of your feet in half). 3. Sit back. Pretend there's a short stool behind you; bend your knees and hips and sit back as if you were going to sit on that stool, while you reach down to grab onto the barbell (hands shoulder-width apart). Actively push your knees out; don't let them collapse in. Keep your back straight so your spine is in a neutral position parallel to the floor. Hinge forward from your hips instead of bending from the waist. [1] X Expert Source Melody Sayers, MS, RD, NASM-CPT Registered Dietician & Personal Trainer Expert Interview Bend your knees and hips just enough to reach and grab onto the bar. This is the starting position for the deadlift. Your shins should be pretty vertical and touching the bar. This is a hard position to stay in. As you figure out your form and check all these criteria, sometimes you'll straighten your legs and allow your back to curve to take a little break from this position. If you watch people deadlift, you'll see them do this between deadlifts. Just make sure you get back into this position before you actually lift. 4. Check your grip. Grasp the barbell with your hands slightly more than shoulder width apart, just outside of your legs. Keep your arms straight. Your palms should face your body, and be equally far from the ends of the barbell. It's not uncommon for people to use a mixed grip as they move onto heavier weights, as it affords a stronger grip, but it's generally better to keep things simple as a beginner. For Olympic lifting, some people use the hook grip, which is more secure but is painful at first. It is similar to the overhand grip, except that instead of the thumb over the remaining fingers, it is hooked underneath them. The underhand grip alone is not recommended because it can lead to the rupture of bicep muscle and connecting tendons, especially in people who do not have full flexibility in the elbow joint. 5. Set your starting position. "Setting" here means creating tension in your body while you're in the starting position so you use your muscles when you pull the bar up. It's a bit like clenching your body; you don't want to be like a wet noodle at all because then you might pull a muscle or hurt a joint. Always make sure your back is completely flat and straight. Keep your head, shoulders, and back in alignment. [2] X Expert Source Melody Sayers, MS, RD, NASM-CPT Registered Dietician & Personal Trainer Expert Interview If there is any kind of bend in your back, you need to do some flexibility work before deadlifting. If you have someone record you in starting position, you'll be able to see whether your back is straight or not. Your hips should be above your knees and your shoulders should be above the hips while slightly over the bar. Engage your core and keep your weight heavy in your heels. [3] X Expert Source Melody Sayers, MS, RD, NASM-CPT Registered Dietician & Personal Trainer Expert Interview Make sure you are looking at the ground in front of you (about 45 degrees) to avoid strain on your neck when performing the lifting portion of the deadlift. 6. Stand up and bring the bar up with you. Raise your hips and shoulders at the same rate while maintaining a flat back. Keep your abs tight during the whole lift. Begin the movement by lifting the slack out of the bar. This is done by pulling the bar slightly up until you feel resistance. If you are using metal plates, you will hear a slight clanging noise. This engages all of the muscles prior to committing to the lift. Next, lift the weight while pushing through the middle of your foot, straightening your knees while pulling your shoulders and head back, and pushing your hips forward after the bar has reached just below the knee. The bar should drag along your shins on the way up--that's why a lot of people who deadlift wear pants or knee-high socks, and if they don't, they often have bruises or scrapes to show for it. Come to a standing position with upright posture and your shoulders pulled back (don't let your shoulders cave forward, think of always pinching your shoulders back together and sticking your chest up and out). Don't bend backwards at all, just stand up straight. Engage (squeeze) your hamstrings and glutes to pull the bar up. Avoid locking your knees. [4] X Expert Source Melody Sayers, MS, RD, NASM-CPT Registered Dietician & Personal Trainer Expert Interview 7. Lower the bar. Keeping your back straight, return the bar to the starting position in a controlled manner. Push your butt out as if you are going to sit down in a chair. Do not arch your back or curl your tailbone under. [5] X Expert Source Melody Sayers, MS, RD, NASM-CPT Registered Dietician & Personal Trainer Expert Interview Release the weight after it is on the ground. 8. Place two dumbbells on either side of your body. The dumbbells should be slightly in front of your feet. Make sure that the weight of your dumbbells is appropriate for your strength. 9. Position yourself properly. Your feet should be spread slightly wider than your shoulders. Point your toes forward. You could also point them slightly outward; the result will be the same. 10. Squat down and grasp the dumbbells. You should squat with a flat, neutral back. Make sure that your shoulders are pulled away from your ears. Keep your head in line with your spine, though if it more comfortable you can tilt your chin up slightly. Make sure that your gaze remains straight ahead (if your eyes wander, so will your head, which will in turn shift your spine.) Make sure that your chest is lifted. Make sure that your heels stay firmly on the floor, and that your shoulders are slightly in front of the balls of your feet. 11. Keep your core strong while you stand up. Your elbows should be straight and the dumbbells should rest by your sides against your thighs. Your hips and shoulders should rise up and straighten at the same time. You should try to keep the dumbbells as close to your body as possible while you straighten up. 12. Hinge at the knees to lower the dumbbells back down. Your hips should move backwards and down as you begin to squat back down to the ground. Try to avoid bending your knees so that they are far ahead of your toes. Keep your back straight and avoid curling your tailbone in or arching your back. Make sure to keep your abs strong and engaged while you lower back down. ## Text steps: Conventional Deadlift (proper form)

1. Setup

* Feet hip-width, toes slightly out.
* Barbell starts centered over your **midfoot** (roughly over your shoelaces), shins ~1–2 in (3–5 cm) away.
* Hands just outside legs; arms straight.

2. Hinge to the bar & grip

* Push hips back to reach the bar while keeping your back neutral.
* Then bend knees until shins lightly touch the bar (bar stays over midfoot).
* Grip: double-overhand to start; use hook or mixed grip only when the weight gets heavy.

3. Set your back & brace

* “Chest up, lats tight” (pull shoulder blades down toward your back pockets).
* Take a deep belly breath and brace your core as if preparing for a gentle punch.
* Hips slightly above knees; shoulders just in front of the bar; neck neutral.

4. Drive the floor away

* Push through midfoot/heels to break the bar from the floor.
* **Hips and chest rise together**; keep the bar close—dragging up shins and thighs.

5. Finish (lockout)

* As the bar passes the knees, drive hips forward and squeeze glutes to stand tall.
* Knees and hips fully extended, ribs down. **Do not lean back** or shrug.

6. Lower & reset

* Hinge first (hips back) to slide the bar down your thighs to knee level.
* Then bend knees to return the bar to the floor over midfoot.
* Release breath, re-brace, and repeat each rep from a dead stop.

### Quick cues

* “Midfoot, lats tight, big breath, push the floor, keep bar close.”

### Common mistakes to avoid

* Rounding the lower back; hips shooting up first; bar drifting forward; bouncing reps; hyperextending at lockout.

### Safety & loading

* Start light and master the pattern: 3–5 sets of 3–5 reps with 1–3 reps in reserve.
* If anything hurts (sharp/pinching pain), stop and consult a qualified coach or clinician.

question:
I am preparing a figure to illustrate different pipelines for video anomaly detection (VAD) using vision-language models (VLMs). The figure should compare three approaches:

1. **Pipeline 1**: A frozen VLM is used for video description and relies on an external LLM for reasoning. The final decision (normal or abnormal) is made using coarse-labeled training data.
2. **Pipeline 2**: Instruction tuning is applied to the VLM, allowing it to describe and reason jointly. This approach requires training on instruction datasets with frame-level annotations.
3. **VERA (our method)**: Introduces VAD guiding questions to query a frozen VLM, enabling it to describe and reason without instruction tuning. The guiding questions are learnable and derived from coarsely labeled data.

In the figure, visually distinguish between frozen modules, learnable modules, inference, and training steps. Show side-by-side comparisons for these three methods, and use example video frames to indicate both test input and training sets.

Please generate:
 1. A comparative diagram of the three VAD pipelines with appropriate arrows, color codes, and labels.
 2. A separate caption summarizing the figure. Provide the image and caption separately.
reference_text: Figure 1. VERA renders frozen VLMs to describe and reason with learnable guiding questions learned from coarsely labeled data.
generated_text:
# Figure Caption (separate)

**Figure X: Side-by-side comparison of three VAD pipelines using VLMs.**
**(Left) Pipeline 1 — Frozen VLM + External LLM:** test video frames are captioned by a **frozen VLM** (blue); an **external LLM** performs reasoning, and a small **decision head** is trained only with **coarse-labeled videos** (dashed training arrows) to output *Normal/Abnormal*.
**(Middle) Pipeline 2 — Instruction-Tuned VLM:** the VLM becomes **learnable** (orange) and is **instruction-tuned** to *describe + reason* jointly using **instruction datasets with frame-level annotations** (green). The tuned VLM feeds a decision head at inference (solid arrows).
**(Right) VERA — Our Method:** **learnable VAD guiding questions** are trained from **coarse labels** and used to **query a frozen VLM**, eliciting descriptions and reasoning *without instruction tuning*; only the question module and decision head are learned.
**Legend:** Frozen modules = blue, learnable modules = orange, datasets = green, **solid** arrows = inference, **dashed** arrows = training.

question: I keep mixing up the layers of Earth's atmosphere. Can you walk me through them and show how they change with altitude? Provide an image and explain.
reference_text: The Earth has five different layers in its atmosphere. The atmosphere layers vary by temperature. As the altitude in the atmosphere increases, the air temperature changes. The lowest layer is the troposphere, it gets some of its heat from the sun. However, it gets most of its heat from the Earth's surface. The troposphere is also the shortest layer of the atmosphere. It holds 75 percent of all the gas molecules in the atmosphere. The air is densest in this layer.
generated_text:
# Text (explanation)
Here’s a quick walkthrough of each atmospheric layer, from the ground up, and how temperature changes with height. (Use the diagram above as the visual.)

**1) Troposphere (\~0–8 km at poles; \~0–18 km at tropics)**

* **What it is:** The weather layer—clouds, storms, and most water vapor.
* **Temperature trend:** **Decreases** with altitude (air expands and cools).
* **Top boundary:** **Tropopause** (often around −50 to −60 °C); its height varies with latitude and season.

**2) Stratosphere (\~10–50 km)**

* **What it is:** Home of the **ozone layer**; commercial jets often cruise in the lower stratosphere (smooth, stable air).
* **Temperature trend:** **Increases** with altitude because ozone absorbs UV sunlight and warms this layer.
* **Top boundary:** **Stratopause** (temperature peaks near 0 °C).

**3) Mesosphere (\~50–85 km)**

* **What it is:** Where many **meteors burn up**; very thin, cold air.
* **Temperature trend:** **Decreases** with altitude (little ozone heating, strong radiative cooling).
* **Top boundary:** **Mesopause**—the **coldest** part of the atmosphere (often \~−90 °C).

**4) Thermosphere (\~85–600+ km)**

* **What it is:** Very thin gas that’s strongly affected by the Sun; overlaps the **ionosphere**, where **auroras** occur and radio signals refract.
* **Temperature trend:** **Increases sharply** with altitude (atoms absorb energetic solar radiation); kinetic temperatures can be very high, though the air is too thin to feel “hot.”

**5) Exosphere (\~600–10,000 km)**

* **What it is:** The outer fringe where atoms can escape to space; satellites orbit here (and in the upper thermosphere).
* **Temperature trend:** Stays **high** in kinetic terms, but particle density is extremely low.

---

## How key properties change with altitude

* **Pressure & density:** Drop off **exponentially**—half the atmosphere’s mass is below \~5–6 km; \~99% is below \~30 km.
* **Temperature profile:** Alternates with altitude due to different **heating mechanisms**

 * Cooling in the **troposphere** (expansion) → warming in the **stratosphere** (ozone UV absorption) → cooling in the **mesosphere** → warming in the **thermosphere** (solar extreme-UV absorption).
* **Composition:** Below \~80–100 km is the **homosphere** (well-mixed composition). Above that, lighter gases become more common (start of the **heterosphere**).
* **Ionosphere:** Not a separate “layer” by altitude alone; it **overlaps** the mesosphere/thermosphere (\~60–1,000 km) and is defined by ionization from solar radiation (important for auroras and radio).

If you’d like, I can add typical Celsius/°F scale values on the temperature curve or include example altitudes for planes, balloons, meteors, the ISS, and GPS satellites.

question: What is an ionic bond and how does it form in lithium fluoride (LiF)? Please answer with both an image and a written explanation.
reference_text: This diagram shows the ionic bonds in lithium fluoride molecule. An ionic bond is the force of attraction that holds together positive and negative ions. The lithium fluorine molecule consists of one lithium atom and one fluorine atom with the chemical formula of LiF. The lithium ion has one more proton than the number of electrons thus has the charge of +1. The fluorine ion has one more electron than the number of protons thus has the charge of -1. The lithium ion and fluorine ion have equal but opposite charges so they attract each other. By the attracting force, they form a lithium fluoride molecule.
generated_text:
# Written explanation

**What is an ionic bond?**
An ionic bond is the electrostatic attraction between positively and negatively charged ions that forms after one atom transfers one or more electrons to another. It’s not a “shared pair” (like in a covalent bond); it’s a non-directional Coulombic attraction between opposite charges.

**How it forms in lithium fluoride (LiF):**

1. **Start with neutral atoms**

* Lithium (Li): 1s² 2s¹ → one valence electron.
* Fluorine (F): 1s² 2s² 2p⁵ → seven valence electrons.

2. **Electron transfer**

* Lithium loses its single 2s valence electron:
  Li → Li⁺ + e⁻
* Fluorine gains that electron to complete an octet:
  F + e⁻ → F⁻

3. **Ionic attraction and crystal**

* The resulting ions attract strongly: Li⁺ + F⁻ → **LiF(s)**.
* In the solid, countless Li⁺ and F⁻ ions pack into a rock-salt lattice, where each Li⁺ is surrounded by six F⁻ (and vice versa). This **lattice energy** makes LiF very stable, hard, and high-melting.

**Why it happens**
Lithium easily gives up its loosely held valence electron (low ionization of the outer electron), while fluorine strongly attracts an extra electron (high electron affinity). The large electronegativity difference drives electron transfer; the lattice’s electrostatic stabilization locks the ions into the solid.

---

*Image is shown above. (You asked for image and text separately, so the picture is separate from this explanation.)*

question: How does the alignment of the Sun and Moon cause a spring tide? Provide an image and brief explanation.
reference_text: Spring tides occur after new or full moons when Sun, Moon, and Earth are aligned. The combined gravitational force creates the largest tidal ranges.
generated_text:
**Image (diagram):**
*Spring Tides — Sun–Earth–Moon Alignment*
(Shows new moon and full moon syzygy with aligned gravitational pulls, reinforcing tidal bulges and producing higher highs & lower lows.)

**Text (brief explanation):**
A **spring tide** happens during the **new moon** and **full moon** when the **Sun, Moon, and Earth line up** (syzygy). In this alignment, the Sun’s tidal pull **adds to** the Moon’s stronger tidal pull, so the ocean’s tidal bulges line up along the Sun–Moon–Earth line. The result is a **larger tidal range**: **higher high tides** and **lower low tides** than average, occurring about **every two weeks**. Local coastline shape, depth, and weather can modify the exact heights.

question: What are flatworms and roundworms, and how do they differ? Use the diagram to help explain.
reference_text: Flatworms are simple invertebrates with bilateral symmetry. Roundworms have a body cavity and complete digestive system. Both can be free-living or parasitic.
generated_text:
# Text explanation (separate from the image)

**What they are**

* **Flatworms (Phylum Platyhelminthes)**: Soft-bodied, dorsoventrally flattened animals. Many are free-living (e.g., planarians), and many are parasitic (flukes, tapeworms).
* **Roundworms (Phylum Nematoda)**: Unsegmented, cylindrical worms found everywhere—especially in soil and aquatic habitats—with many free-living and parasitic species (e.g., pinworms, hookworms, *C. elegans*).

**Key differences (matching the diagram)**

* **Body cavity**

  * Flatworms: **Acoelomate** (no internal body cavity; solid tissue between gut and body wall).
  * Roundworms: **Pseudocoelomate** (fluid-filled cavity acts as a hydrostatic skeleton).

* **Digestive system**

  * Flatworms: Usually **incomplete gut** (one opening); tapeworms have **no gut** and absorb nutrients through their surface.
  * Roundworms: **Complete gut** with **mouth → pharynx → intestine → anus**.

* **Body covering**

  * Flatworms: Free-living forms have a **ciliated epidermis** for gliding; parasitic forms have a protective **tegument**.
  * Roundworms: A tough, flexible **collagen cuticle** that they **molt** as they grow.

* **Muscles & movement**

  * Flatworms: **Circular, longitudinal, and dorsoventral muscles**; glide using cilia and muscle undulations.
  * Roundworms: **Longitudinal muscles only**; move with characteristic **thrashing** due to the hydrostatic pseudocoelom.

* **Excretion/osmoregulation**

  * Flatworms: **Protonephridia (“flame cells”)** with cilia that drive fluid through tubules.
  * Roundworms: **Excretory canals/renette cells** along the body.

* **Nervous system**

  * Flatworms: **Anterior ganglia (“brain”)** with **ladder-like** transverse connections between longitudinal nerve cords.
  * Roundworms: **Nerve ring** around the pharynx with prominent **dorsal and ventral nerve cords**.

* **Reproduction**

  * Flatworms: Often **hermaphroditic**; many can **regenerate** lost parts (notably planarians).
  * Roundworms: Usually **dioecious** (separate sexes) with **sexual dimorphism**.

* **Shared traits**

  * Both are **bilaterally symmetrical**, **triploblastic** (three tissue layers), and **lack specialized circulatory/respiratory organs**—gas exchange occurs by diffusion.

**Quick summary**

| Trait                | Flatworms (Platyhelminthes)            | Roundworms (Nematoda)               |
| -------------------- | -------------------------------------- | ----------------------------------- |
| Shape                | Flattened                              | Cylindrical, round in cross-section |
| Body cavity          | None (**acoelomate**)                  | **Pseudocoelomate**                 |
| Gut                  | Incomplete or absent                   | Complete (mouth → anus)             |
| Covering             | Ciliated epidermis/tegument            | Thick molted cuticle                |
| Muscles              | Circular + longitudinal + dorsoventral | Longitudinal only                   |
| Movement             | Glide + smooth undulations             | Thrashing                           |
| Excretion            | Flame cells (protonephridia)           | Excretory canals/renette            |
| Nervous system       | Ladder-like cords                      | Nerve ring + cords                  |
| Typical reproduction | Hermaphroditic; regeneration common    | Separate sexes                      |

If you want any changes to the diagram (different labels, colors, or a simpler version for younger students), tell me and I’ll regenerate it.

question: How do you use a compound light microscope properly? Use the diagram to help explain.
reference_text: A compound microscope has parts like eyepiece, objective lenses, stage, and coarse/fine focus knobs. Always carry it by the arm and base. Use focus knobs and lenses to adjust image clarity.
generated_text:
Here’s the image and the explanation kept separate, just like you asked.

# 1) Diagram (labeled parts)

*(See the image above.)*
The figure shows a compound light microscope with the light path and numbered callouts for each component.

---

# 2) How a compound microscope works (with parts explained)

## Big picture

A compound microscope uses **two lens systems**—the **objective** near the specimen and the **eyepiece (ocular)** near your eye—to create **high total magnification**. Light from the **illuminator** is focused through the specimen by the **condenser**. The **objective** forms a **real, inverted intermediate image** inside the tube; the **eyepiece** then magnifies that into the **virtual image** you see.

**Total magnification = (eyepiece power) × (objective power).**
**Resolution** (smallest detail you can separate) improves with higher **NA** of the objective/condenser and with shorter wavelengths of light.

## What each numbered part does (match to the image)

1. **Eyepiece (ocular)** – Magnifies the intermediate image made by the objective; often 10×. Some models include a **diopter** ring to match focus between your eyes.

2. **Head / Body tube** – Holds the optics at fixed spacing so the objective image forms at the correct plane for the eyepiece.

3. **Revolving nosepiece (turret)** – Clicks different **objective lenses** into the light path quickly.

4. **Objectives (4×, 10×, 40×, 100× oil)** – The primary magnifiers; also the main drivers of **resolution** and **working distance**.

   * **4× (scanning):** wide field, easy to find the specimen.
   * **10× (low):** more detail, still forgiving.
   * **40× (high dry):** fine detail; use **fine focus only**.
   * **100× oil:** highest detail; requires immersion oil to boost NA and resolution.

5. **Stage** – Platform that holds the slide. Often a **mechanical stage** with **X–Y controls** for precise movement.

6. **Slide & stage clips** – Secure the specimen directly over the light path.

7. **Coarse focus knob** – Moves the stage quickly to find focus at low power.

8. **Fine focus knob** – Small, precise motion for sharp focus, especially at 40×/100×.

9. **Condenser** – A lens system that concentrates light onto the specimen; usually raised close to the underside of the slide for brightfield.

10. **Iris diaphragm (substage)** – Adjustable aperture beneath the condenser. **Open** for brightness and resolution; **close** for more contrast (but less resolution). Use together with the condenser height.

11. **Field diaphragm (if present)** – Controls the illuminated field size; helps set Köhler illumination and reduce stray light.

12. **Illuminator / LED** – The light source. Often paired with a **brightness control** on the base.

13. **On/Off & brightness control** – Powers the lamp and sets intensity to a comfortable, non-glary level.

14. **Arm** – Structural support; the safe handle when carrying the scope (other hand under the base).

15. **Base & power connector** – House the lamp and electronics; provides stability.

### What’s happening to the image?

* **Illuminator → condenser → specimen:** Light is focused into a cone that passes through the specimen. Transparent/colored areas transmit or absorb light differently, creating contrast.
* **Specimen → objective:** The objective produces a **real, inverted** magnified image inside the tube.
* **Objective image → eyepiece:** The eyepiece acts like a magnifier, creating a **virtual image** your eye focuses on.
* **Result:** High magnification with limited depth of field; tiny focus adjustments and proper illumination are crucial.

If you want, I can make a printable one-page “How it works + parts” handout using this same diagram.

question: I'm learning about self-supervised learning. How does SimSiam work without using negative pairs or momentum encoders? Please explain the architecture and training strategy with an image and short description.
reference_text: SimSiam is a minimalist self-supervised learning method that avoids both negative sample mining and momentum encoders. It uses two augmented views of the same image, processed by a shared encoder. One view passes through an additional predictor MLP, while the other applies stop-gradient to avoid representation collapse. The model maximizes similarity between the outputs without contrastive loss, relying only on architectural asymmetry to learn meaningful representations.
generated_text:
SimSiam is a self-supervised learning method that avoids using negative pairs or momentum encoders by relying on a simple architecture with two augmented views of the same image. The key idea is to use a Siamese network structure, where both augmented views are passed through separate encoders. The encoders produce representations of the images, which are then passed to a predictor (a small MLP) to generate predictions.

The critical component here is the "stop-gradient" operation applied to one of the branches, which prevents the gradients from propagating through it during backpropagation. This allows the model to learn by comparing the predictions of the two augmented views, pushing them to match without relying on negative samples.

In the training process, the model uses a loss function (usually cosine similarity) that minimizes the distance between the predictions from the two views.

question: I'm studying the Flamingo model architecture, specifically the Gated XATTN-DENSE layer. Can you explain how this layer works and its components?
reference_text: The Gated XATTN-DENSE layer in Flamingo is a crucial component that combines gated cross-attention and gated feed-forward layers to process vision and language inputs. It performs self-attention on the language input and cross-attention with the vision input. The layer includes gating parameters, alpha_xattn and alpha_dense, to control the contribution of the attention and feed-forward operations. The layer outputs language features enhanced with visual information, allowing the model to process multimodal data efficiently.
generated_text:
Text (separate from the image):

# What is the Gated XATTN-DENSE layer?

In Flamingo, this is the multimodal **adapter** inserted into a frozen language model (LM) so token representations can **attend to visual latents** while keeping the LM’s original behavior largely intact. It’s a two-part block:

1. a **gated cross-attention (XATTN)** sublayer, and
2. a **gated feed-forward (“DENSE”/MLP)** sublayer, each wrapped with pre-LayerNorm and residual connections.

---

## Inputs

* **Text hidden states** (H \in \mathbb{R^{T\times d}}): current LM token embeddings.
* **Visual latents** (Z \in \mathbb{R^{M\times d_v}}): a fixed set of tokens produced by the Perceiver Resampler from one or more images/video frames.
* (Learned) **gating projections** that turn each token’s state into an element-wise gate.

---

## Step-by-step flow

### 1) Gated Cross-Attention (XATTN)

* **Pre-norm:** (\tilde H = \mathrm{LN}(H)).
* **Cross-attention:** queries (Q) come from (\tilde H); keys/values (K,V) come from (Z).
  [
  A=\mathrm{MHA}(\tilde H W_Q,\; ZW_K,\; ZW_V)
    ]
* **Gate the visual update:** compute a token-wise, channel-wise gate
  [
  g_x=\sigma(\tilde H W_{gx}+b_{gx})\in\mathbb{R^{T\times d}},
    ]
  then modulate the cross-attn output and add residually: [
  H^{(1)}=H + g_x \odot A.
    ]
  The gate lets the layer learn **how much** each token should trust vision, often starting near “closed” so initial behavior matches the base LM.

### 2) Gated DENSE (position-wise MLP)

* **Pre-norm:** (\hat H=\mathrm{LN}(H^{(1)})).
* **MLP/Dense:** (F=\phi(\hat H W_1 + b_1) W_2 + b_2) (with a standard nonlinearity (\phi), e.g., GELU).
* **Gate the MLP update:**
  [
  g_d=\sigma(\hat H W_{gd}+b_{gd}),\qquad
  H_{\text{out}}=H^{(1)} + g_d \odot F.
    ]

---

## Why the gating?

* **Stability with frozen backbones:** The LM (and typically the vision encoder) can remain frozen; new parameters are in the XATTN/DENSE paths and their gates. Gating prevents overwhelming the LM with visual signals early in training and enables smooth **modality balancing**.
* **Token-specific control:** Gates are computed **per token** and **per channel**, so some words (e.g., nouns near image mentions) can open the visual pathway more than others.
* **Regularization by design:** With gates near zero, the block reduces to an identity map, which curbs overfitting and preserves strong language priors.

---

## Placement in Flamingo

These Gated XATTN-DENSE blocks are **interleaved at several points** inside the LM stack. During inference on interleaved image–text streams, each text segment can query the relevant **cached** visual latents via the XATTN, while standard self-attention continues to handle language context.

---

## Summary of components

* **LayerNorm (pre-norm)** before each sublayer
* **Multi-Head Cross-Attention** (Q from text, K/V from visual latents)
* **Learned sigmoid gates** (g_x, g_d) (element-wise modulation)
* **Position-wise MLP (“DENSE”)**
* **Residual connections** after both sublayers

If you’d like, I can annotate the diagram with your preferred symbols (e.g., different gate shapes, head counts, or exact tensor sizes) and export it as SVG or PDF.

question: How to turn off notifications on Instagram? Show visual steps and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. Open your iPhone's Settings . Tap the grey app with gears on it. This app is typically found on the Home Screen. 2. Tap Notifications . It's near the top of the menu. Doing so opens a list of all apps that currently support notifications. 3. Scroll down and tap Instagram . Apps here are listed alphabetically, so you'll find Instagram in the "I" section. If Instagram is not appearing, you may need to wait until you've received a notification from someone. If Instagram is still not appearing in the list, even after receiving a notification in the app, uninstall the Instagram app, restart your phone, and then install it again. When you launch the reinstalled app, select Allow Notifications when prompted, and Instagram should appear in the Notifications section of the Settings app. 4. Tap the white "Allow Notifications" switch . It's at the top of the screen. Tapping it will cause it to turn green , signifying that Instagram will send notifications to your iPhone. If you want to disable Instagram notifications completely, tap the green "Allow Notifications" switch and then skip the rest of this method. 5. Enable or disable other notifications. Tap the white switch to the right of each of the following options to enable them, or tap the green switch next to each of them to disable them: Sounds - Turn on or off Instagram sounds. Badge App Icon - Turn on or off Instagram badge icons, which are the numbers that display in the corner of the Instagram app when you have pending notifications. Show on Lock Screen - Turn on or off notifications that appear on your iPhone's Lock Screen. Show in History - Turn on or off notifications history for Instagram. Notifications history can be checked by swiping down from the top of the screen. Show as Banners - Turn on or off banner-style notifications, which display at the top of the screen when your iPhone is unlocked. 6. Select an alert style. Below the "Show as Banners" switch, tap either Temporary or Persistent . This option won't display if you have "Show as Banners" turned off. "Temporary" alerts appear briefly at the top of your iPhone's screen before disappearing, while "Persistent" alerts don't disappear until you swipe them away. 7. Set a preview option. This will determine whether or not you can see the content of an Instagram notification without opening it. Scroll down and tap Show Previews , then select one of the following options: Always (Default) - You will always see previews for Instagram notifications (e.g., "Sarah liked your post"). When Unlocked - You will see previews for Instagram notifications when your iPhone is unlocked. Never - You will never see previews for Instagram notifications. 8. Tap the "Back" button twice. It's in the top-left corner of the screen. This will take you back to the Notifications page, saving your changes in the process. Instagram will now send you notifications.

   • This silences all push notifications for the time you select.

1. Instagram → **Profile** → **☰** → **Settings** → **Notifications**.
2. Open each category and set to **Off**:

   * **Messages and calls** → toggle **Message requests**, **Messages**, **Group requests**, **Calls**, **Video chats** → **Off**.
   * **Posts, stories and comments** → set items like **Likes**, **Comments**, **First posts and stories**, **Mentions**, etc. → **Off**.
   * **Following and followers**, **Live and Reels**, **From Instagram**, etc. → set each to **Off** as desired.
3. (Optional) Scroll to **Email/SMS** and turn those **Off** if you don’t want emails or texts from Instagram.

## Option 3 — Silence Instagram completely at the phone level (recommended for zero alerts)

### iPhone (iOS)

1. Open **Settings** app → **Notifications** → **Instagram**.
2. Toggle **Allow Notifications** **Off**.

   * (Optional) Also turn off **Sounds**, **Badges**, and all alert styles.

### Android (steps may vary slightly by device)

1. Open **Settings** → **Apps** (or **Apps & notifications**) → **Instagram** → **Notifications**.

   * (Optional) Leave it On and turn individual **Notification categories** Off for fine-grained control.

question: How to check battery health on iPad? Provide steps with screenshots and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. Open your Settings app. The app has a gray icon with a gear on it. You can use this method to check your battery health on any iPad model, including iPad Pro and iPad Air. 2. Navigate to Privacy & Security . You will have to scroll a bit to find this option, as it's at the bottom of the section that begins with General . 3. Click on Analytics & Improvements . It's near the bottom of the screen. 4. Ensure Share iPad Analytics is toggled. If this setting isn't toggled on, your iPad will not generate the logs needed to decipher your battery health. If you just toggled this setting on now, you'll need to wait a minimum of 24 hours for your iPad to create the correct analytics log. 5. Click on Analytics Data . A list of logs should pop up. 6. Find the most recent Analytics log. You are looking for a log that is titled Analytics . The numbers after Analytics are a date, so select the one that is the most recent. Logs titled analyticsd.diskwrites will not work for this method. If you're on iOS 15 or earlier, the correct analytics log will be titled log-aggregated . 7. Copy the log into a text editor. You can use the Notes app on your iPad or you can export the log file to a computer. 8. Search for MaximumCapacityPercent . The number after that phrase is your current maximum battery capacity. This number is a percentage, so if your log gives you a 90 after this number, your battery capacity is at 90%. You can search the log by using Find in Note if you're using the Notes app. Find in Note is located under the three-dot menu in the upper right-hand corner. On a computer, you can use the Find function , which is available in most text editors by clicking Ctrl + F on Windows or Cmd + F Mac. 9. Search for CycleCount . The number after that phrase is the current battery cycle count. Every time your iPad battery is charged from 0 to 100, that counts as a cycle. Apple says that iPads should maintain about 80% of total battery capacity after 1000 cycles.
